conclusion: The working principle of a mass spectrometer is described, including the setup of metal plates M and N, recording plate Q, and interface P dividing regions I and II.
A Cartesian coordinate system Oxyz is established with the z-axis passing through holes a and b, the positive x-axis parallel to plate Q, and the positive y-axis vertically upward.
Region I is filled with a uniform magnetic field along the positive x-axis with strength B, and region II is filled with a uniform electric field along the positive x-axis with strength E.
A particle with mass m and charge +q enters the system from hole a with zero initial velocity, passes through hole b, enters the magnetic field, and finally hits the recording plate Q.
The image shows the mass spectrometer setup with plates M, N, Q, and interface P, along with the coordinate system and fields in regions I and II.
The coordinate system is established with the z-axis passing through holes a and b, and the origin O at the intersection of the z-axis and plate Q.
The electric field strength in region II is calculated using E = U/d, where U is the voltage between plates M and N, and d is the distance between them.
The particle is accelerated by the electric field in region II, with acceleration a = qE/m in the x-direction.
The radius R of the circular path in the magnetic field is determined using the relationship between electric and magnetic forces.
The radius R of the circular path is given by R = qE/mω, where ω is the angular frequency of the circular motion.
The final answer for the radius of the circular path is \frac{m}{qB}.
